conclusion: Analyze the motion of the charged ball under the influence of gravity and electric field to understand electric potential energy changes.
The ball is subject to gravity acting downward with force mg and electric force opposite to electric field with force qE.
Ball moves along a straight line at angle θ opposite to electric field direction, net force along this line.
Resolve forces along direction of motion: gravity component mg sin(θ), electric force component qE cos(θ).
For straight line motion, components must be equal: mg sin(θ) = qE cos(θ).
Change in electric potential energy ΔU is given by work done by electric force.
Work done by electric force is qE times horizontal displacement d cos(θ).
Change in electric potential energy ΔU is negative of work done: ΔU = -qE d cos(θ).
To find d, consider vertical motion component: initial velocity v0 sin(θ), time to highest point when vertical velocity is zero.
Time to highest point t = v0 sin(θ) / g.
Vertical displacement h = v0 sin(θ) t - 1/2 gt^2 = v0^2 sin^2(θ) / 2g.
Total displacement d along path: d = h / sin(θ) = v0^2 sin(θ) / 2g.
Substitute d into ΔU equation: ΔU = -qE v0^2 sin(θ) cos(θ) / 2g.
Final answer: Difference in electric potential energy is ΔU = -qE v0^2 sin(θ) cos(θ) / 2g.
